awd_titl_txt: RAPID: The Rise and Propagation of Anti-Vax and Anti-Access Social Media Campaigns Targeted at Disadvantaged and Minority Populations during the COVID19 Pandemic
awd_abstract_narration:
As long as there have been vaccines, there has been vaccine hesitancy. When vaccine hesitancy leads to lowered vaccination rates, there is a greater risk for preventable illness in communities. Increasingly, vaccination has become a target for misinformation and disinformation offline and online.  Some disinformation purveyors particularly target disadvantaged and minority populations, which for historical reasons may distrust the public health establishment and medical research. Among these groups, distrust in the healthcare system is often accompanied by multiple barriers to healthcare and a heightened susceptibility to  SARS-CoV-2 infection. The research team is conducting quick-response research to better understand the social media mechanisms that threaten COVID-19 vaccination compliance and disinformation targeted at minority and disadvantaged groups. This project explores how anti-vaccine campaigns arise and how they use language and narratives to incite fear of vaccination and rejection of public health messages. An ultimate goal of the project is to further equity in citizen knowledge and public health.  

The primary sites of investigation are social media interactions on Twitter, with supplemental fieldwork in geographical communities. Social media studies will include both quantitative and qualitative analysis methods. Data sets will be created that capture unique terms (commercial vaccine names, those that signal groups targeted for anti-vaccine narratives (e.g., “tuskegee”), those using terms that signal vaccine resistance but are noisier (e.g., “gene therapy”), and those capturing phrases such as (“do your own research”). Retrospective searches are intended to detect the genesis of new anti-vaccine narratives. Finally, supplemental fieldwork using semi-structured interviews conducted in West Dallas investigates if and how online anti-vaccine narratives targeted at Black and Latinx groups appear in geographical space. Students will be involved at all stages of the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were to examine COVID-19 vaccine unintended misinformation and intentional "disinformation" to understand if and how either or both were targeted at vulnerable populations.

Vaccine hesitancy has always been a public health concern, and anti-vaccine campaigns that proliferate false information have gained traction across the US. People give heath, religious, and, increasingly, political concerns as reasons. This project team examined a large online vaccine discussion social media space. Participants made reference to the unethical Tuskegee Syphilis Study (which ran 1932-1972) in this space. Analyses of these discussions suggested anti-vax targeting of Black people as well as genuine discussions of medical racism and vaccine hesitancy. Thus, in the same online groups purposeful disinformation about vaccines was mixed with open, questioning discussion of racism and health care.  

In analyzing disinformation in these social media spaced, the history of the Tuskegee Syphilis Study was retold and released to an audience to sow mistrust. The ease of social media platform use favored the ability to disinform and spread misinformation. The project team believes that human and machine methods of removing acts of disinformation and repeated acts of misinformation are required along with computer mechanisms and policies that encourage and enable a broader readership and balanced discussion.

The project team also investigated how misinformation evolved on a social media platform over time, examining the case of COVID-19 vaccine fears, first in the abstract and eventually in relation to the lived experiences of receiving the vaccine. Throughout, fertility fears were a cornerstone of anti-vaccine campaigns, that is, the argument made was that the vaccine would interfere with women's fertility. These arguments led to some distinct notable beliefs. After the first wave of convergence which consisted of self-reported menstrual disruptions after a COVID-19 vaccination, the second wave collected those experiences of menstrual disruption to show a connection between the vaccines and the disruption. Anecdotes reinforced people’s beliefs about a possible vaccine side effect that was not addressed by medical or public health authorities. The third wave included a persistent anti-vaccine movement that then co-opted the first movement’s own data as evidence of a link between vaccines and female fertility. The effect of the online activity reverberated into the popular press, with the popular press reacting strongly to online activity which helped bring attention to the matter more broadly. Because of the long delay before people were reassured that menstrual disruption was to be expected but is otherwise physiologically harmless—about one year after vaccines were made available—disinforming behaviors fueled by worry and the ready presence of anti-vaccine activists became prominent. The results suggest that when marginal topics are neglected by public health experts and medical professionals, they may support and help fuel anti-vaccine beliefs and campaigns.

Modified by: Leysia Palen
